title: الْجُمَلُ الَّتِي لَا مَحَلَّ لَهَا مِنَ الإِعْرَابِ
description: Learn about the six types of sentences that have no grammatical position (i'rab): opening sentences, resumptive sentences, relative clauses, oath responses, explanatory sentences, and parenthetical sentences.

notes.title: Introduction to Sentences Without Position
notes.titleArabic: مُقَدِّمَةٌ فِي الْجُمَلِ الَّتِي لَا مَحَلَّ لَهَا
content: In Arabic grammar, sentences (جُمَل) can either have a grammatical position (مَحَلّ) or not. A sentence has a position when it can be replaced by a single word - for example, a sentence functioning as خَبَر is في مَحَلِّ رَفْعٍ (in the position of nominative).

However, six types of sentences have NO grammatical position. These sentences cannot be replaced by a single word and serve structural or contextual functions rather than syntactic ones. Mastering these is essential for classical Arabic text analysis.
keyPoints: الجملة ذات المحل: can be replaced by a single word
الجملة التي لا محل لها: cannot be replaced by a word
Six types of sentences have no grammatical position
Essential for i'rab of classical texts

examples.english: Zayd is standing (opening sentence - no position)
The one who came (relative clause - no position)
By Allah, I will certainly do it (oath response - no position)

notes.title: The Opening Sentence (الجملة الابتدائية)
content: The الجملة الابتدائية is the sentence that opens speech (افتتاح الكلام). It is the first sentence in a discourse that is not dependent on anything before it.
This sentence has no grammatical position because there is nothing preceding it to give it a position. It simply begins the speech.
keyPoints: Opens speech - first sentence in discourse
Not dependent on preceding elements
Has no i'rab position because nothing precedes it
Common at the beginning of chapters, speeches, and narratives

examples.english: Praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds (opening of Fatiha)
Allah Most High said (opens a citation)
There was, in ancient times, a king
Know that... (opens instructional text)

notes.title: The Resumptive Sentence (الجملة الاستئنافية)
content: The الجملة الاستئنافية is a sentence that begins a new topic or thought after a previous sentence. Though it follows other speech, it is grammatically independent - it 'resumes' with fresh content.

It differs from الجملة الابتدائية in that something precedes it, but it differs from connected sentences in that it has no grammatical link to what came before. Often introduced by فَ (fa) or وَ (wa) of استئناف.
keyPoints: Begins new topic after previous speech
Grammatically independent of preceding
Often introduced by وَ or فَ استئنافية
No position because it starts fresh

examples.english: Zayd is standing, and Amr is sitting (new topic)
A bearer of good news and warner has come to you (Quran 5:19)

examples.arabic: قُلْ هُوَ اللهُ أَحَدٌ. اللهُ الصَّمَدُ
examples.english: 'Allah the Eternal' begins a new statement (Quran 112:2)
Then peace be upon you (resuming with greeting)

notes.title: The Relative Clause (جملة صلة الموصول)
content: The جملة صلة الموصول is the sentence that comes after a relative pronoun (الَّذِي، الَّتِي، مَا، مَنْ, etc.) to complete its meaning. This sentence defines or describes what the relative pronoun refers to.
Though this sentence is essential for meaning, it has no grammatical position because it is considered part of the relative pronoun itself - together they form one unit (الموصول + الصلة).
keyPoints: Follows relative pronouns (الَّذِي، الَّتِي، مَا، مَنْ)
Completes meaning of the relative pronoun
No position: forms one unit with الموصول
Must contain a returning pronoun (عَائِد)

examples.english: The one who succeeded came (نَجَحَ = صلة)
I read what you wrote (كَتَبْتَهُ = صلة)
Those who believed and did righteous deeds (Quran)
Whoever does evil will be recompensed for it (Quran 4:123)

notes.title: The Oath Response (جملة جواب القسم)
content: The جملة جواب القسم is the sentence that comes after an oath (قَسَم) to state what is being sworn about. Arabic oaths consist of two parts: the oath formula (المُقْسَم به) and the response (جواب القسم).
The response sentence has no grammatical position because it is the purpose of the oath - it is what the speaker is affirming, not a grammatical component.
keyPoints: Follows oath formulas (وَاللهِ، تَاللهِ، بِاللهِ)
States what is being sworn about
Often begins with لَ or إِنَّ for emphasis
No position: serves as oath's purpose

examples.english: By Allah, I will certainly do it
By Allah, Allah has preferred you over us (Quran 12:91)
By time, indeed mankind is in loss (Quran 103:1-2)
By Allah, he is indeed truthful

notes.title: The Explanatory Sentence (الجملة التفسيرية)
content: The الجملة التفسيرية explains or clarifies something mentioned before it. It is introduced by أَيْ (meaning 'that is') or أَنْ التفسيرية, or it may come without a particle.
This sentence has no position because it merely restates or clarifies - it doesn't add new grammatical content but illuminates what was already said.
keyPoints: Explains or clarifies previous content
Introduced by أَيْ or أَنْ التفسيرية
Can come without an introducing particle
No position: restates rather than adds

examples.english: We inspired him: 'Build the ark' (Quran 23:27) - أَنِ اصْنَعِ = explanatory

examples.arabic: هَلْ أَدُلُّكُمْ عَلَى تِجَارَةٍ... تُؤْمِنُونَ بِاللهِ
examples.english: Shall I guide you to a trade... You believe in Allah (Quran 61:10-11)
I signaled to him to go (أَنِ اذْهَبْ explains the signal)
I wrote to him (saying) 'Do it'

notes.title: The Parenthetical Sentence (الجملة الاعتراضية)
content: The الجملة الاعتراضية is a sentence inserted between two grammatically connected elements for emphasis, prayer, or clarification. It 'interrupts' the flow without being part of the main structure.
Common insertions include prayers (رَحِمَهُ اللهُ), clarifications, and emphatic statements. The sentence has no position because it is external to the main sentence's grammar.
keyPoints: Inserted between connected elements
Often prayers, clarifications, or emphasis
Interrupts without being part of main structure
No position: external to main grammar

examples.arabic: قَالَ الشَّافِعِيُّ - رَحِمَهُ اللهُ - في كِتَابِهِ
examples.english: Al-Shafi'i - may Allah have mercy on him - said in his book

examples.arabic: إِنَّ الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا - وَاللهُ يَعْلَمُ - لَا خَوْفٌ عَلَيْهِمْ
examples.english: Those who believe - and Allah knows - no fear upon them
Zayd - I think - is standing
He is - and praise be to Allah - a scholar

exercises.prompt: الْجُمْلَةُ الَّتِي تَفْتَتِحُ الْكَلَامَ تُسَمَّى الْجُمْلَةَ _____
exercises.promptEn: The sentence that opens speech is called the _____ sentence

exercises.prompt: الْجُمْلَةُ بَعْدَ الْمَوْصُولِ تُسَمَّى جُمْلَةَ _____ الْمَوْصُولِ
exercises.promptEn: The sentence after the relative pronoun is called the _____ of the relative

exercises.prompt: الْجُمْلَةُ الَّتِي تُفَسِّرُ مَا قَبْلَهَا تُسَمَّى الْجُمْلَةَ _____
exercises.promptEn: The sentence that explains what precedes it is called the _____ sentence

exercises.prompt: الْجُمْلَةُ الْمُعْتَرِضَةُ بَيْنَ الْعَنَاصِرِ الْمُتَّصِلَةِ تُسَمَّى الْجُمْلَةَ _____
exercises.promptEn: The sentence inserted between connected elements is called the _____ sentence

exercises.prompt: وَاللهِ لَأَفْعَلَنَّ - جُمْلَةُ لَأَفْعَلَنَّ تُسَمَّى جُمْلَةَ _____ الْقَسَمِ
exercises.promptEn: By Allah I will do it - the sentence لَأَفْعَلَنَّ is called the _____ of the oath

exercises.prompt: الْجُمْلَةُ الَّتِي تَبْدَأُ مَوْضُوعًا جَدِيدًا بَعْدَ كَلَامٍ سَابِقٍ تُسَمَّى الْجُمْلَةَ _____
exercises.promptEn: The sentence that begins a new topic after previous speech is called the _____ sentence

exercises.answer: The relative clause (completing the relative pronoun)

exercises.prompt: A sentence that explains or clarifies what came before it
The sentence that comes after an oath to state what is being sworn about
A sentence that resumes with a new topic after previous speech
